name: Kepler-363
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-363 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-363 is a star with 1.9249999999999994 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.49 times its radius. It is located 2543.23 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-363 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-363 b

Kepler-363 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.61 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-363.

The mass of Kepler-363 b is 1.36 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-363 b is 1.16 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-363 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-363 c

Kepler-363 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.54 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-363.

The mass of Kepler-363 c is 3.40 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-363 c is 1.69 that of Earth. At 3.40 Earth masses, Kepler-363 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-363 d

Kepler-363 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.93 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-363.

The mass of Kepler-363 d is 5.40 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-363 d is 2.05 that of Earth. At 5.40 Earth masses, Kepler-363 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-363, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
